conversation.content: Did you ever finish [cough] that installation at the museum?

Oh man, so, that whole project turned into, you know, this massive headache when the curator decided, um, halfway through setup that the entire concept needed to shift from abstract to literal narrative.
They changed it halfway through? That's brutal.

Yeah, I had, like, already mapped out forty-two projectors across three floors, and then suddenly, er, they wanted everything reconfigured for, honestly, this completely different storytelling approach with synchronized timelines.
How do you even handle that professionally?

Well, you smile and nod while, um, internally [shaky voice] calculating how many all-nighters it's going to take, and then, you know, you basically rebuild everything from scratch while pretending it's no big deal.
Sounds like, uhh, you need better contracts or, I mean, penalty clauses for changes that late.
Contracts are great until you're dealing with [bored] prestigious institutions who know they can blacklist you from the entire museum circuit if you don't play nice with their whims.
That's some serious [bored] power dynamic nonsense right there.

The worst part is, well, knowing that the original concept was, hmm, actually [anxious] better but having to pretend their new direction is brilliant while basically, you watch your artistic vision get dismantled piece by piece.
Wait, did they at least [confused] pay you for the extra work?
They threw in, uh, an extra five percent which, you know, [cheerful] barely covered the additional equipment rental, but hey, at least I got to, actually, add another major museum to my portfolio.
Five percent? That's [playful] almost insulting.
Right? But here's the thing, in projection design you're, sort of, always walking this tightrope between artistic integrity and, well, keeping the lights onâ€” literally and figuratively speaking.
Do you ever, like, just want to tell them no? I mean, set some real boundaries?
Every single day, but then, umm, rent comes due and suddenly you're, actually, agreeing to project butterflies onto a ceiling for some tech CEO's daughter's, er, sweet sixteen party.
Butterflies? That's, honestly, kind of a comedown from museum work, uhh, isn't it?
You'd think so, but those private events actually [confused] pay triple what museums do, and the clients usually just let you do whatever as long as it looks expensive and photographs well.
So you're telling me, well, the real money is in, basically, rich kids' parties and not, um, actual art installations?
Welcome to the creative industry where your most profound artistic statement might get you exposure while projecting someone's Instagram handle in glitter pays your actual bills.
